awd_titl_txt: Assessing Student Abilities and Enhancing Value Added in Higher Education for Disadvantaged Students: Evidence from the U.S. Military Academy in West Point
awd_abstract_narration:
Institutions of higher education confront a common set of challenges: assessing the capabilities of applicants and selecting those best suited to the mission of the institution, fostering diversity, inculcating knowledge, and placing graduates in productive careers. This research provides methods to help colleges and universities evaluate how well they are meeting these challenges and also help them become more effective. The investigators study the U.S. Military Academy at West Point (USMA). The USMA is an excellent setting to study these issues for several reasons: The USMA awards degrees in a range of academic majors comparable to those offered in many colleges and universities. The USMA undertakes comprehensive assessment of capabilities of applicants. Likewise, the measures of progress made over the course of a student's studies are more comprehensive than those obtained by other academic institutions. Finally, assessment of career accomplishments of graduates is enhanced by the fact that the graduates of the service academies all initially work for the same employer. With this comprehensive data, this project assesses current practices and prescribes policies to attract, retain, and improve performance of disadvantaged students. This research will be valuable not only to USMA but also to researchers and policy makers seeking to improve the effectiveness of our nation's colleges and universities.

All colleges and universities confront common challenges: assessing capabilities of applicants, deciding which to admit, fostering diversity, inculcating knowledge, and placing graduates in productive careers. Responsibility for these activities is typically dispersed, with little coordination, across different administrative and teaching units. The investigators undertake an integrated analysis of these activities for a selective college, the U.S. Military Academy at West Point. The USMA offers a range of majors comparable to that of other undergraduate institutions. It undertakes comprehensive assessments of applicants and comprehensive assessments of performance as students progress through college, obtaining more extensive measures than are obtained by other academic institutions. It has retained these measures for a large number of cohorts as well as measures of career performance. This project assesses the extent to which achievement gaps across demographic groups are narrowed by the college. This research characterizes the relevant dimensions of skills and estimates a model of admission, attrition, and achievement. The investigators examine potential changes in admission and retention policies that may improve achievement, graduation rates, and career success, with particular emphasis on improving access and success in higher education by disadvantaged groups.

por.por_cntn:
The growing importance of higher education for economic success coupled with rapidly rising tuitions are bringing increasing pressure on colleges to undertake assessments of their effectiveness in educating a diverse student body. Supreme Court decisions have mandated that college actions to promote diversity must be based on clear, measurable, and non-discriminatory criteria. These pressures highlight the need for colleges to undertake systematic collection of data on students’ entering credentials, performance while in college, and placement. An assessment strategy is then needed to compare outcomes of majority and minority students with comparable entering qualifications. The proviso “comparable entering qualifications” is of particular importance, given differences in college readiness between minority and majority students.

We develop such an assessment strategy. To demonstrate the value of this approach, we apply the assessment strategy to West Point, a selective college ranked 15th among US Liberal Arts Colleges. The database maintained by West Point is a model that other colleges and universities can emulate. Study of West Point is of interest in its own right. Our contribution is also of broader interest. Our methodology can fruitfully be employed by other colleges and universities to assess their performance. We use a similar approach to assess male-female relative performance and the effectiveness of the one-year college preparatory program operated by West Point.

To explain our methodology, it is useful to place the approach in the context of West Point. Applicants to West Point are ranked by a Whole Candidate Score (WCS). This score is in turn based on scores on measures of academic preparation, leadership, and physical fitness, with academics receiving 60% weight, leadership 30%, and physical fitness 10%. Black and Hispanic minority students have lower academic and leadership scores. This is expected because minority students experience greater pre-college disadvantage than many of their non-minority peers. Hence, for meaningful investigation of educational progress of minority relative to non-minority students, it is important to compare students with comparable entering qualifications. We therefore adopt an approach called matching. We find a subset of white students with entering academic, leadership, and fitness scores comparable to those of black students. We also match on gender and whether the student had prior service or attended at the West Point preparatory school. We then compare achievement, attainment, and earlier career outcomes of these closely matched students. We undertake the same analysis for Hispanic students, applying matching to find entering white students with qualifications that closely match those of entering Hispanic students.

We find that black students at West Point have somewhat lower achievement than their matched white counterparts. However, graduation rates and early career outcomes are not adversely impacted by this differential achievement. To the contrary, we find virtually identical graduation rates and early career outcomes for black students and matched white students. This is an encouraging finding of our analysis. Of course, achievement is also important. The analysis that we have undertaken is valuable in identifying this as an area where attention is needed.

We find small insignificant differences in achievement measures, graduation rates, and early career outcomes for Hispanic students and their matched white counterparts. Thus, on all measures, Hispanic students perform equally well as their matched white counterparts.

Applying the matching methodology to compare outcomes of men and women, we find that women have lower graduation rates than men, and women are less likely than men to stay in the military beyond the five-year time commitment required of all West Point graduates. We find comparable achievement of male and female graduates.

We believe that the approach we developed in this project can be used fruitfully by many colleges and universities to assess their effectiveness in educating a racially diverse student body. As well, these institutions can assess their effectiveness in educating both men and women.  The approach can potentially be applied to most undergraduate programs.  Examples that seem particularly well suited to such assessment are programs in engineering and the physical sciences, computer science, business and economics, data science, and pre-med programs.  The approach can also be used by professional schools including business, law, nursing, and education.

We also investigate the effectiveness of the US Military Academy Preparatory School (USMAPS) operated by West Point. The fraction of minority students at USMAPS is higher than at West Point. Using USMAPS data, we again use matching so as to provide meaningful comparisons of gains of minority and non-minority students. We find that both minority and matched majority students have large and statistically significant gains in both academic and leadership skills from attending the West Point preparatory school. This finding is of much practical importance. Indeed, the success of this one-year preparatory program naturally raises the question of whether a college preparatory program for other selective colleges and universities might have similar success.
